revision.comment: [[WP:AWB/T|Typo fixing]], typos fixed: Managment → Management, Reconcilation → Reconciliation using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
A "module" is a group of related programs performing a major function within an ERP. Since there is no particular order that makes sense, we have chosen to list the modules in alphabetical order. Some of the decisions about what constitutes a module are arbitrary. Since an ERP is designed to accommodate a variety of industries, not every enterprise would use every module.
[[/Layout | Module Documentation Layout]] describes how the information about each module is organized.
An ERP package is composed of the following modules:
Finance and Performance Management *[[/Accounts Payable | Accounts Payable]] *[[/Accounts Receivable | Accounts Receivable]] *[[/Bank Reconciliation | Bank Reconciliation]] *[[/Cash Management | Cash Management]] *[[/Currency | Currency]] *[[/Fixed Assets | Fixed Assets]] *[[/General Ledger | General Ledger]] *[[/Bond Manager | Bond Manager]] *[[/Job Costing | Job Costing]] *[[/Time Billing | Time Billing]] *[[/Investment Manager | Investment Manager]] *[[/Share Manager | Share Manager]]
Customer Relationship Management *[[/Customer Relationship Management | Customer Relationship Management (CRM)]] *[[/Help Desk | Help Desk]] *[[/Call Center | Call Center]] *[[/Contacts | Contacts]] *[[/Sales Analysis | Sales Analysis]] *[[/Sales Compensation | Sales Compensation]]
Human Resource Management *[[/Employee Scheduling | Employee Scheduling]] *[[/Human Resources | Human Resources]] *[[/Payroll | Payroll]]
Supply-Chain Management *[[/Inventory | Inventory]] *[[/Manufacturing | Manufacturing]] *[[/Order Entry | Order Entry/Invoicing]] *[[/Preventative Maintenance | Preventative Maintenance]] *[[/Pricing | Pricing]] *[[/Purchasing | Purchasing]] *[[/Quotation | Quotation/Estimation]] *[[/Receiving | Receiving]] *[[/Shipping | Shipping]] *[[/Service Management | Service Management]]
Technical Architecture *[[/Systems Administration | Systems Administration]] *[[/Business Intelligence | Business Intelligence (BI)]] *[[/Workflow | Workflow]]
[[Category:{{FULLBOOKNAME}}|{{FULLCHAPTERNAME}}]]

== Welcome message ==
Hello, and '''[[Wikibooks:Welcome, newcomers|welcome]]''' to [[Wikibooks]]!
Here are some tips to help you get started: * To learn the wiki-markup-language syntax, see [[Help:Editing]]. * You should sign your name on Talk and vote pages using four tildes, like this: ~~~~ **There is a box at the top of the edit window that will insert this, too; it looks like part of a signature. * Remember to conduct any editing experiments in the [[Wikibooks:Sandbox|sandbox]]. * You can tell the community something about yourself in your userpage. ** You can get to this page by clicking the tab at the top of the page labeled with your registered username. * If you are a '''Wikipedian''', see [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikipedians]] for a primer on how things work here (it's a little different). ** If you want to base your work here on materials from Wikipedia, please use [[WB:RFI]] (requests for importation) to bring the material over in compliance with the GFDL. * If you're an '''instructor''' and plan on using Wikibooks for a class project, see [[Wikibooks:Guidelines for class projects]] * Please say hello at the [[WB:SL|Staff Lounge]] with any questions or ideas. * Eventually, you might want to read the [[Wikibooks:Manual of Style|Manual of Style]] and [[Wikibooks:Policies and guidelines|Policies and Guidelines]]. ** Please take a look at [[Wikibooks:Naming policy]] before starting a new book. * Remember to maintain a [[Wikibooks:Neutral point of view|Neutral point of view]]. * Explore, [[Wikibooks:Be bold in updating pages|be bold in editing pages]], and have fun!
You will find more resources in [[Wikibooks:Community Portal|Community Portal]]. If you want to ask a question, visit the [[Wikibooks:Study help desk|Study help desk]], the [[Wikibooks:Staff lounge|Staff lounge]], [[Wikibooks:IRC channels|IRC channel]] or ask me personally on my talk page. For site news, see the [[WB:BB|Bulletin board]]. It might be a good idea to add this page to your "watchlist" so that you can see when any new information is posted there. You can do that by clicking the tab labeled "watch" at the top of the page.
Good luck! --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] 17:17, 15 April 2007 (UTC)

== Introduction == Currency defines the valid currencies for the system and keeps tracks of their conversion rates. This information is used by General Ledger to determine gains and losses on exchange. Most ERP packages have a Currency module.
*[[/Functions | Functions]] *[[/Reports | Reports]]
== Tables == The group of tables consists of the Currency table which contains one record for every currency used by the ERP and the Currency Rate table which contains one record for every conversion rate for every currency. There is at least one conversion record for every currency and there can be many. ==Data Exchange== Currency does not send or receive transactions to/from other modules. == Transactions ==
[[Category:{{FULLBOOKNAME}}/Modules|Currency]]

An Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) package is a computer software package that integrates all departments and functions within an enterprise into a single, integrated system that maintains a single, integrated set of data. Any transaction entered in one area causes an immediate update in related areas. An ERP enables departments to share information and communicate with each other much better and more quickly using one consistent set of numbers available to all users.
[[Category:{{FULLBOOKNAME}}|{{FULLCHAPTERNAME}}]]

A "module" is a group of related programs performing a major function within an ERP. In a few cases modules contain sub-modules.
[[Category:{{FULLBOOKNAME}}|{{FULLCHAPTERNAME}}]]

A bill of materials (BOM) lists the quantity of raw materials and parts that are required to manufacture a product. Often the BOM includes the quantity of operations (cutting, welding, machining, etc.) that is required as well. Each line on a BOM can itself be a BOM.
[[Category:{{FULLBOOKNAME}}|{{FULLCHAPTERNAME}}]]

revision.comment: what about linking a mosimage to another image?
revision.text: This is useful, but what about having the image link to a larger version of itself? This is a very common practice and I think one of the mosimage parameters should be an optional choice of *another* image from the library that it will link to when clicked.

== Summary == This scene follows the advice of [[Blender 3D: Noob to Pro/Modeling Realistically]], which suggests modeling with multiple parts that have been measured carefully, just like they were constructed.
The cans consist of four aluminum parts:
* pull-tab
* rivet
* press-shaped cap
* concave-bottomed cylinder
This simplified the UV-layout work on the can too, since only one part needed any UV coordinates.
The floor consists of many identical copies of the same board, rotated randomly for variation.
The glass is one mesh, with an inside and an outside surface. This helps the raytracer give realistic curvature effects near the lip of the glass.
== Licensing == {{PD-self}}

revision.comment: This skateboard is modeled using techniques recommended in [[Blender 3D: Noob to Pro/Modeling Realistically]]. The deck, wheels, alloy trucks, nuts, grip area, sidewalk and weeds were all different objects using various materials. This gives the most fl
revision.text: == Summary == This skateboard is modeled using techniques recommended in [[Blender 3D: Noob to Pro/Modeling Realistically]]. The deck, wheels, alloy trucks, nuts, grip area, sidewalk and weeds were all different objects using various materials. This gives the most flexibility for any changes to be made later. == Licensing == {{PD-self}}

[[Image:Stop_hand.svg|left|30px]] Welcome to Wikibooks. We invite everyone to contribute constructively to our collection. Take a look at the [[Wikibooks:Welcome, newcomers|welcome page]] if you would like to learn more about contributing. However, unconstructive edits are considered [[Wikibooks:Vandalism|vandalism]], and if you continue in this manner you may be '''blocked from editing without further warning'''. Please stop, and consider improving rather than damaging the hard work of others. Thanks. --[[User:Herbythyme|Herby]] [[User talk:Herbythyme|talk thyme]] 20:50, 21 January 2007 (UTC)

Welcome to the Wikibook series of
'''Mathematics in volumes'''
''This project is in its infancy and all progressive structural amendments are welcomed. To discuss anything related to this series of textbooks, please use the [[User_talk:User:Herraotic/Mathematics in volumes|talk page]]'' == Scope == The scope of 'Mathematics in volumes' is to provide a free, in both meanings of the word, textbook series. The series will cover the introduction to the form of a number and what it represents all the way to hyperbolic functions. == Intended reading == The intended reading order is to initially examine the pupil with a test provided that is referenced to his age. If the pupil receives a score under 80 percent, the student should undertake that corresponding textbook until the pupil scores over 80 percent. If the student fails an initial test, 4a for example, they should do 4b or 4c. If they fail both, they must undergo the initial test again receiving at least 90 percent or over, the cycle reoccurs by increasing by 5 percent, though at a point of failing to receive the required 100 percent the student will be demoted to an easier textbook. The corresponding question textbooks should be used with the general textbooks. == Textbooks == Legend: ME is the abbreviation of Mathematics Elementary MI for Mathematics Intermediate MA for Mathematics Advanced ME1 ME2 ME3 ME4 ME5 ME6 ME7 ME8 ME9 MI1 MI2 MI3 MI4 MA1 MA2 MA3 MA4 MA5 MA6 MA7

This '''[[Wikijunior|Wikijunior]]''' book is designed to teach you, in less than a year, all of the mathematics you'll need to pass a lower level college.
Not everyone has the good fortune to be taught their numbers and letters before entering kindergarten, but everyone can learn to do math well.
This book begins at the beginning. It assumes you know how to read, nothing else. (If you have trouble reading this, you need to learn reading first, but you can work on math, too, if you have someone to read to you.)
The book is organized in a series of short lessons. Each lesson starts by saying what it is designed to teach. If you already know what that lesson is designed to teach, skip to the next lesson. '''Do not skip any lesson you are not absolutely certain you know'''. Every lesson builds on what has gone before.
If you want more instruction, especially gearing up for college, read [[Wikijunior:More_on_Mathematics|More on Mathematics]]. It was made for the average reader to be able to understand it.
== Table of Contents == #[[/Numbers/]] #[[/Counting/]] #[[/Adding/]] #[[/Subtracting/]] #[[/Multiplying/]] #[[/Dividing/]] #[[/Order of Operations/]] #[[/Negative Numbers/]] #[[/Fractions/]] #[[/Decimals/]] :[[/Glossary/]]
{{Subjects|Wikijunior School Time}} {{Alphabetical|I}} {{status|50%}}

The Chart of Accounts contains one record for every General Ledger account.
Used by: General Ledger
Key: Account Number
Fields *Account Number (a unique identifier assigned by the user, commonly composed of segments) *Description *Active (Yes/No) *Type (Asset/Liability/Equity/Income/Expense) *Normal Balance (Debit/Credit) *Omit from financial statements if zero (Yes/No) *Allow job allocations (Yes/No) *GIFI *Notes
[[Category:{{FULLBOOKNAME}}|{{FULLCHAPTERNAME}}]]

This includes a group of tables. They are listed below:
*[[/Contact | Contact]] *[[/Contact Interaction | Contact Interaction]] *[[/Contact Person | Contact Person]]
[[Category:{{FULLBOOKNAME}}|{{FULLCHAPTERNAME}}]]

This table contains one record for every contact.
Used by: Contacts
Key: Contact Number
Fields: *Contact Number (a unique identifier assigned by the user) *Type *Organization/Individual (individual must have exactly one person record) *Active (Yes/No) *Group *Name *Address 1 *Address 2 *City *State/Province *Country *Zip/Postal Code *Telephone *FAX *E-mail *Website *Referred By *Sales Representative Number *Last Interaction Date *Next Interaction Date *Territory *Notes
[[Category:{{FULLBOOKNAME}}|{{FULLCHAPTERNAME}}]]

This table contains one record for every interaction between the business and the contact. Although contacts are not yet customers, this table is key to Customer Relationship Marketing.
Used by: Contacts
Key: Contact Number, Date/Time
Fields: *Contact Number *Date/Time *Type (Telephone,Face-to-face,etc.) *Employee Number(s) *Location *Contact Attendees *Notes
[[Category:{{FULLBOOKNAME}}|{{FULLCHAPTERNAME}}]]

This table contains one record for every person at every contact.
Used by: Contacts
Key: Contact Number, Person Number
Fields: *Contact Number *Person Number (a unique identifier assigned by the user) *Last Name *First Name *Informal Name *Job Title *Department *Title (Mr/Ms/Mrs/etc.) *Address 1 *Address 2 *City *State/Province *Country *Zip/Postal Code *Business Telephone *Telephone Extension *Home Telephone *FAX *Mobile *Pager *E-mail *Language *Gender *Marital Status *Birthdate *Notes
[[Category:{{FULLBOOKNAME}}|{{FULLCHAPTERNAME}}]]
[[Category:Vedic Mathematics|Redirects]]

This group of tables control who can log on to the company and what functions they can perform. Each user can be assigned one or more roles (such as Purchasing Agent) which gives them access to a variety of functions. This allows the Systems Administrator to define a limited set of roles and allocate those roles to a large group of users. In smaller enterprises, the Systems Administrator would simply assign functions to each user directly.
The contents of these tables are encrypted to increase security.
== User == This table contains one record for every user that can log into this company.
Used by: Every function in every module
Key: User Number
Fields: *User Number (a unique number assigned by the ERP package) *User Name *User Password *Password Expiry Date *Minimum Password Length *Inactive (Yes/No) *Employee Number *Language *Notes
== Role == This table contains one record for each role.
Used by: Every function in every module
Key: Role Number
Fields: *Role Number *Role Description *Notes
== User Role == This table contains one record for each role each user has.
Used by: Every function in every module
Key: User Number, Role Number
Fields: *User Number *Role Number
== User Access == This table contains one record for every function the user can perform in this company. Although this is how the data is stored, the ERP uses a more compact format for efficiency reasons.
Used by: Every function in every module
Key: User Number, Function Number
Fields: *User Number *Function Number *Type of Access
== Role Access == This table contains one record for every function the role can perform in this company. Although this is how the data is stored, the ERP uses a more compact format for efficiency reasons.
Used by: Every function in every module
Key: Role Number, Function Number
Fields: *Role Number *Function Number *Type of Access
== Functions == The ERP package has pre-defined tables that list all the possible functions that can be performed as well as all the types of access.
[[Category:{{FULLBOOKNAME}}|{{FULLCHAPTERNAME}}]]

revision.comment: [[WP:AWB/T|Typo fixing]], typos fixed: ie → i.e. using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
This includes a group of tables. They are listed below:
*[[/Customer | Customer]] *[[/Customer Interaction | Customer Interaction]] *[[/Customer Location | Customer Location]] *[[/Customer Person | Customer Person]]
In some enterprises customers are individual people. In others, they are other enterprises with one or more locations and contacts. Finally, many enterprises have a mixture of both individuals and enterprises. This group of tables is structured so that each customer can have one or more locations that have one or more contacts to accommodate all three possibilities.
'''Donors''' In the case of not-for-profit enterprises "donors" are "customers" (i.e. the source of revenue). They use fund-raising, grant management, and donor management to raise funds.
[[Category:{{FULLBOOKNAME}}|{{FULLCHAPTERNAME}}]]

This table contains one record for every customer.
Used by: Accounts Receivable, Order Entry/Invoicing
Key: Customer Number
Fields: *Customer Number (a unique identifier assigned by the user) *Type *Organization/Individual (individual must have exactly one person record) *Active (Yes/No) *Territory *Group (used to group national accounts together) *Name *Address 1 *Address 2 *City *State/Province *Country *Zip/Postal Code *Shipping Address (same fields as above billing address) *Telephone *1-800 Number *FAX *E-mail *Website *Price List *Discount Percentage *Produce Statement (Yes/No) *Sales Representative Number *Credit Limit *Usual Terms *Usual FOB *Usual Ship Via *Usual Currency *Sales Representative ID *Backorders Allowed (Yes/No) *COD (Yes/No) *NAICS *Referred By *Preferred Invoice Delivery Mode *Language *Current Accounts Receivable Balance (a calculated field that the user cannot change) *YTD Sales (a calculated field that the user cannot change) *Customer Since (date) *Holdback Percentage *Holdback Days *GL Distribution Group (contains all the postable account numbers) *Notes
[[Category:{{FULLBOOKNAME}}|{{FULLCHAPTERNAME}}]]

This table contains one record for every person at every customer.
Used by: Accounts Receivable, Order Entry/Invoicing
Key: Customer Number, Customer Location Number, Person Number
Fields: *Customer Number *Customer Location Number *Person Number (a unique identifier assigned by the user) *Last Name *First Name *Informal Name *Job Title *Department *Title (Mr/Ms/Mrs/etc.) *Address 1 *Address 2 *City *State/Province *Country *Zip/Postal Code *Business Telephone *Telephone Extension *Home Telephone *FAX *Mobile *Pager *E-mail *Marital Status *Birthday *Language *Notes
[[Category:{{FULLBOOKNAME}}|{{FULLCHAPTERNAME}}]]

This table contains one record for every interaction between the business and the customer. This table is key to Customer Relationship Marketing.
Used by: Accounts Receivable, CRM
Key: Customer Number, Date/Time
Fields: *Customer Number *Date/Time *Type (Telephone,Face-to-face,etc.) *Employee Number(s) *Location *Customer Attendees *Notes
[[Category:{{FULLBOOKNAME}}|{{FULLCHAPTERNAME}}]]

Such things are discs of mashed potato that have been battered and deep-fried; great if you want your fats, carbs and salt all in one nasty tasting hit. revision.comment: [[Valatine]] moved to [[User:Jmoinian/Valatine]]: Blatant disregard for Wikibooks policies after repeated warnings
revision.text:
Once again the New Year had come and with it a New Valentine is approaching. The big greeting card companies as well as retails are advertising to buy a Diamond for your Sweetheart and make that special one happy with a reservation on such and such big restaurant name and surprise her by sending dozens of roses to her door step. Retails have always have plans for your valets. But do you really know what Valentine is? Let’s shine some lights on this important matter.
Valentine was a Christian Priest whom lived during Claudius II on the third century A.D. These were thought times for Christians since they were consider traitor. Emperor of Rome was against anyone whom was worshiping some other entity. Many Christians suffered unbearable torture and death. Valentine and his fellow believers met secretly in different places including caves. The legend has it that Valentine sent heart shape cart cut out of parchment to comfort the unfortunate imprisoned Christians.
Emperor Claudius was a selfish man; he banned marriage among his soldiers. Claudius believed that his soldiers have to have one devotion ant that was only him. Married soldiers will have his devotion reduced because of wife and children. So, Valentine performed the hold marriage vow in secret. When Claudius found out about this great importance became so outraged that he declared Valentine an enemy of state. By the order of empire Valentine was arrested and thrown into the horrible jail for years.
One day the good priest was dragged before the Roman emperor Claudius. The charge of being good Christian was accepted by the devoted priest. Claudius was very curious by now. So, he asked the priest to speak about his Christian beliefs. The good Priests knowledge won the admiration of Claudius. But Valentine hurried to convert Claudius to Christianity which made the king very furious. Valentine advised Claudius to give up the false goods made of woods and stones and worship the one true God. Everyone at the king’s palace was outraged. The senators condemned Valentine to death. Claudius whom was impressed by Valentine spared his life by turning him over to his trusted lieutenant Asterius. He ordered Asterious to force Valentine renounce his beliefs in true one God, and worships the Roman goods. The lieutenant took Valentine to his home and showered him with kindness. But neither kindness nor harsh treatments changed Valentine’s belief in true God.
In Asterius household Valentine encountered the young daughter of Asterius whom was blind from both eyes. Astrerius told the good priest of many visits to Apollo temple. All the prayers and all the trips to different shrine were no use. Her eye sight was not restored. Valentine asked Asterius persmission to resotre his daughter’s eye sights. At first Asterius pleaded to Valentine not to expose his daughter to another disappointment. At the end Asterius gave in and with the permission of Asterius the prayer begun.” A light filled the room, and the young lady was given the gift of sight.”
The girl’s father was stunned; he was convinced the Valentine’s true God is more powerful and mighty than Roman God. Asterious, his family, as well as his slaves were baptized by St. Valentine. The news of Asterious bet real of Roman god reached Claudius. He sentenced Asterieus and his entire household including St. Valentine to death.
On February 14TH around the year 270 A.D. St. Valentine was taken outside the city to the Flaminian Gate. There he was beheaded and buried. Ever since then the name of the Gate changed to Valentine’s Gate; an unknown person planted an almond tree, a symbol of love and friendship near Valentines’ grave. The almond tree blooms’ every year on February 14T; to cherish the memory of a great saint lets remember him on Valentines Day.
